sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using Gaussian elimination
message_1:
The following system of linear equations needs to be solved using Gaussian elimination:

$x+2y-3z=7$

$2x-3y+z=-1$

$3x+y-2z=5$

Find the values of $x$, $y$, and $z$ that satisfy all three equations simultaneously.
message_2:
To solve the system of linear equations using Gaussian elimination, we first write the augmented matrix:

$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & -3 & 7 \\ 2 & -3 & 1 & -1 \\ 3 & 1 & -2 & 5 \end{bmatrix}$

Step 1: Eliminate the $x$ terms below the first row.

Subtract 2 times the first row from the second row, and subtract 3 times the first row from the third row:

$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & -3 & 7 \\ 0 & -7 & 7 & -15 \\ 0 & -5 & 7 & -16 \end{bmatrix}$

Step 2: Divide the second row by -7 to get a leading 1 in the second row:

$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & -3 & 7 \\ 0 & 1 & -1 & 15/7 \\ 0 & -5 & 7 & -16 \end{bmatrix}$

Step 3: Eliminate the $y$ terms below the second row.

Add 5 times the second row to the third row:

$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & -3 & 7 \\ 0 & 1 & -1 & 15/7 \\ 0 & 0 & 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$

Step 4: Divide the third row by 2 to get a leading 1 in the third row:

$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & -3 & 7 \\ 0 & 1 & -1 & 15/7 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & 1/2 \end{bmatrix}$

Now we perform back substitution:

From the third row, we have $z = 1/2$.

From the second row, we have $y - z = 15/7 \Rightarrow y = 15/7 + 1/2 = 22/7$.

From the first row, we have $x + 2y - 3z = 7 \Rightarrow x = 7 - 2(22/7) + 3(1/2) = 7 - 44/7 + 3/2 = 49/14$.

So the solution is $x = 49/14$, $y = 22/7$, and $z = 1/2$.
